msDesc.head: Miscellany of courtly poetry by Hoccleve, Lydgate, Peter Idley, Chaucer; English, 1450s–90s

supportDesc.foliation: Flyleaves unnumbered. The manuscript has been foliated twice: firstly, an older ink foliation which numbers every tenth folio and the last folio, regularly inconsistent by 5 folios; secondly, a modern pencil foliation which numbers fols. 1–93 correctly and emends the older ink foliation. There are catchwords on fols. 17v and 35v only.
supportDesc.collation: 118-1 (fols. 1-17; first excised), 220 (fols. 18–37), 32 (fols. 38–39), 416-2 (fols. 40–53; fifteenth and sixteenth lacking) | 524 (fols. 54–77), 68-6 (fols. 78–79; second, third, fourth, fifth, seventh, and eighth lacking), 714 (fols. 80–93). Collation following D. W. Mosser, A new collation for Bodleian Digby MS 181, Papers of the Bibliographical Society of America, 82 (1988), 604-11.
supportDesc.condition: Front board detached. Some pages affected by damp in the lower and upper margins. Significant staining in the first quire and at the break between quires 1 and 2. Occasional tears.

binding.p: Standard Digby binding with armorial stamp with two metal clasps, c. 1632–34.

history.provenance: Inscribed, this is John Fayerproutes bock, 16th century (fol. 77v).
Inscribed, John [ ]pper, 17th century (fol. 93v), visible under UV light (see Michael C. Seymour, The manuscripts of Chaucer's Troilus, Scriptorium, 46:1 (1992) ).
Peter Idywerte: inscribed, 17th or 18th century ? (first parchment flyleaf, a pastedown to a previous binding), possibly a bastardisation of Peter Idley.
Kenelm Digby, 1603–1665: inscribed, Vindica te tibi Kenelme Digby (fol. 1r).

msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.title: Letter of Cupid
msItem.incipit:
To hire name ȝhit is it no reprefe
ffor all to vertu was þat she wrowght
msItem.explicit:
The yeer of grace ioyfull and iocound
A thowsande foure hundrede the secunde
msItem.finalRubric:
Explicit littera Cupidinis directa
Subditis suis Amatoribus

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Pain and Sorrow of Evil Marriage
msItem.incipit:
[G]lory vnto God laude and benyson
To Iohn to Petir & also to Laurence
msItem.explicit:
Wherfore yonge menne, to eschewe sorowe & care
Withdrawe your foot or ye ffall in the snare

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Examples against Women
msItem.incipit:
[T]O Adam and Eve Crist gave the soueraigte
Of Paradice and domynacioun
msItem.explicit:
Some renne in riote of custome this is no faile
Suche woll disceyue there nature is so frayle

msItem.author: Peter Idley
msItem.title: Instructions to his Son
msItem.rubric: [I]nicium mei tractus sit in nomine domini Ihesu Christi a quo ...
msItem.incipit:
In the begynnyng of this litle werke
I pray god my penne to lede
msItem.explicit:
Safe only nature þe which doth me spede
To the my Childe to þis simple dede

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A Complaynt of the Black Knight
msItem.incipit:
[I]N May whanne fflorra the lusty Quene
The soill hath cladde in grene rede and whight
msItem.explicit:
Exiled be that I may not atteyne
Recouer to ffynde of myne aduersite

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Anelida and Arcite
msItem.incipit:
[O] Thowe fers god of armes mars the rede
That in thy ffrosty Cuntre called Trace
msItem.explicit:
With in the Temple with a sorowfull chere
That Shapyn was as ye shall aftir here

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Parliament of Fowls
msItem.incipit:
The life so short the crafte so longe to lerne
The assay so harde so sharpe the conqueryng
msItem.explicit:
That I shall mete some thyng for to fare
The bettir and thus to rede I woll not spare
msItem.finalRubric:
Explicit
Here endith the parlement of ffowlis

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fall of Princes
msItem.rubric:
Where Bochas repreuyth hemme þat yeue
hasti credence to euery report or tale
msItem.incipit:
All though so be in euery maner Age
ffolkis been dyuers of Condicions
msItem.explicit:
Bethe circumspect not hasty but prudent
And yeuyth no credence without auysement
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit expliceat sic scriptor ludere eat

supportDesc.support: Paper. Fols. 1-17: ‘Armoires-Pal’ (Briquet, 2064); fols. 18-53: ‘Armoires-Trois Fleurs de Lis’ (similar to Briquet, 1725).

layoutDesc.layout: Frame ruled in ink (faded) in 34-44 long lines. 202 70

handDesc.handNote: Daniel W. Mosser identifies the scribe as John Brode, whose hand also appears in John Rylands Library, MS. English 113 (copied c.1475–1500). Brode may also be responsible for the anadrome, Explicit Edorb quod (fol. 39r). See Daniel W. Mosser, The Scribe of Chaucer Manuscripts Rylands English 113 and Bodleian Digby 18, Manuscripta, 34 (1990), 129-47.

decoDesc.decoNote: A space of two to three lines left for initials at the beginnings of texts and textual units: fols. 7r, 10v, 31r, 39v, 44r, 52r.

origin.p: Dating from Late Medieval English Scribes.

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Troilus and Criseyde
msItem.incipit:
[T]he dowbill sorowe off Troilous to tell
That was the kyng Priamus sonne of Troy
msItem.explicit:
Vs lakkis nought but þat we witt wolde
A certeyn houre in which she come sholde

layoutDesc.layout: Frame ruled in ink (faded) in 38-42 long lines. 195 70–90

decoDesc.decoNote: A spaces of six to seven lines left for initials at the beginnings of texts and textual units: fols. 54r, 59r, 68r, 69r, 86v, and 87v.
Occasionally, but inconsistently, the first initial of the leaf is flourished.

origin.p: The Troilus has watermark dated 1457 which is also found in MS. Bodl. 414.
Dating from Late Medieval English Scribes.
